newsitem.title: USA: United Airlines, flight attendants reach pact.
newsitem.headline: United Airlines, flight attendants reach pact.

text.p: Flight attendants at United Airlines said Monday they reached a tentative contract agreement with the nation's largest airline.
The union declined to provide terms of the tentative pact, but union spokeswoman Jill Gallagher said, "We did meet our primary goals of getting raises, retirement and respect."
"From an economic standpoint, it maintains the United flight attendants' position in the industry," said Association of Flight Attendants International President Pat Friend.
Industry analysts said that United's flight attendants are among the highest paid in the industry.
In Chicago, United said the new contract would run through the year 2006.

Negotiators for the Association of Flight Attendants said the tentative agreement was reached Saturday after a 25-hour final bargaining session. The pact requires approval by the airline's 22,000 flight attendants based in 20 cities in the United States, Europe, Asia and South America.
The union and the airline have been in talks since March 1996.
The agreement with the flight attendants follows United's recent contract agreements with the pilots and machinists unions.
Friend declined to comment on how the flight attendants' pact compares to those reached with the machinists and pilots, but she said negotiators felt they were "comparable."

The pilots' recent agreement calls for two wage increases of 5 percent. In the year 2000, the pact also restores wage rates to levels that existed before July 1994, when certain United employees agreed to wage reductions in exchange for a majority-ownership stake in the company.
The flight attendants did not take part in the 1994 employee stock ownership plan. United is owned by UAL Corp.
